You have set the laws at defiance, and long reign'd uncontrouled, I confess, but don't wonder if the subjects of your slander forget there are laws in their turn, and valuing an honest name more than their lives, should expose their lives to revenge it.

SP.SPEAKER: O'FLAM.
SP.P:
Upon my soul, Mr. Margin, very wholsome adviee, and will do you much good if you take it; but, above all, rid your hands of James Anonymous as soon as you can, you know it
was he got you that beating.—That fellow has brought you into more scrapes than all your au∣thors together.

DIV3.STAGE: Etner Lady RISCOUNTER, LUCY, and KITTY.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Sir James Biddulph is gone?

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, and with him my master.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Sir Robert! to what place, can you guess?

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: I should think, by what I overheard, to the printer's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: To the printer's! of what use can that be?

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: I can't say; but your ladyship, I hope, will excuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Excuse you, why child, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: I have heard some whispering among the clerks, as if things were not quite so well with my master.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: What, some little disappointments in trade?

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: Much worse, I am afraid, I don't know what it means; but they say an extent is brought into the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: With all my heart; let what will happen, it can be of little importance to me.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: No, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: My child, you can't suppose, but upon my marriage, at all events, to secure a proper pro∣vision.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Indeed! can that be done?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: A common caution, my dear, don't you see Mrs. Paduasoy rides in her coach, whilst half her husband's creditors are in gaol.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Is that the case?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P:
If wives were to have any thing to do with
those kind of creatures, who d'ye think would marry with people in business? and now I think on't, it will be so much the better; for the fa∣ther's failure must in some measure fall on the daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: True; but your ladyship saw Sir James Bid∣dulph.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: For a moment only, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Well, Madam, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: I only just threw out a hint, to be more ex∣plicit now, would make him suspicious, we must give him time to digest his disappointment.

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: As I live, Miss Lydia is coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Lydia!

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: I beg your ladyship's pardon, for intruding without your permission; but, my unfortunate situation will, I hope, plead my excuse: I come, Madam, to beg your protection.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Mine, child?

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: Your assistance, in detecting the authors of this horrid design.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: That, child, is properly your father's con∣cern.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: True, Madam; but the relation your lady∣ship bears to his family might, I hope, induce you to do me this justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Justice, Lydia, as it is my duty, I shall ever be ready to give my advice.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: That, Madam, is all that I want.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: As this affair has made such a noise, there re∣mains but one step to be taken.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: Which is—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: A marriage with James.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: With James! and so sanctify the scandalous story.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: It may be alledged by the family, that the ceremony had pass'd before the detection.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: Detection! I hope your ladyship does not sup∣pose there is the smallest foundation?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: That I shall not pretend to determine. But, at all events, you are in the right to deny it.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: Your ladyship's indifference shocks me more than the—Your daughter, Lucy, will do me justice I am sure, she has been privy to every—

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Me, Miss? I beg pardon for that: how should I know your Intrigues? I beg you will not involve me in your guilt.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: Nay, then it is in vain to struggle, I see; my ruin is resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Where is Lady Riscounter? well, my dear, we have got to the bottom of this infernal busi∣ness at last—here, here it is, in the rascal's own hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Sir Robert!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Why, the paragragh was sent to the printer's by James.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: So that you see proves the forgery plain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Now I think it makes the fact more apparent.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: By the confession of one of the parties.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: That I confess, as it was voluntary.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Makes it amount to a positive proof.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: It looks very suspicious indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Here my lady, Sir James, thinks, that instead of clearing, this paper only serves to convince her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: Is that your ladyship's judgment?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Quite to a demonstration, Sir James.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: But his policy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Obvious enough; to force the family to soli∣cit his marrying the girl, as a favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: That, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: With the hopes, perhaps, of obtaining some additional advantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: In return, no doubt, for his great condescen∣sion. An infamous—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: I should have thought the young lady's pri∣vate fortune, and person, especially to one of his rank, a very sufficient inducement. But this Mr. James is an absolute Machiavel.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: As sly a dog as ever existed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: But could not we see him, Sir Robert?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: The rascal is run off.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: We have search'd for him all the town over.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: That is unlucky, as I should have been glad to have ask'd him a question. I believe it is unnecessary to apologize to the family, for any part I take in this business.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: We are all highly obliged.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: But I have received a letter, the contents of which astonish me much.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: About the matter in hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: Indeed the writer is but a dependant of mine, but his veracity is out of the question, the facts must speak for themselves. Mrs. Kitty, you will be kind enough to stay here for a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: What can be the meaning of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: If the charge is false, I am sure, Lady Ris∣counter will pardon me for the sake of the mo∣tive. If true, she, in her turn, will stand in want of all our forgiveness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Me! who will dare to impeach my conduct, Sir James?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: Your ladyship's patience, a moment. This paper, Sir Robert, charges Lady Riscounter with being the sole contriver of this villainous project.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: With a view of dissolving the contract be∣tween your fair daughter and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: To what purpose? what end?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: One that does me too much honour, I own, the bringing about a union between Miss Lucy and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: A most probable story, indeed: your infor∣mer's name, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: A servant who has oft attended me here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: And he receiv'd it from—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: One of your ladyship's women; there she stands, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: Is it possible that you, Kitty—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Patience, Lydia, a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: And you think this paltry plot, obviously fram'd by a couple of servants, (unless you con∣descend to be the contriver yourself) will justify you in bringing this charge against a person of my rank and condition.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Fie, fie, Sir James, that is too presumptuous indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: Why, I should not have ventur'd, I believe, if I had not to produce a more unexceptionable witness than these.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Name the person directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: Lady Riscounter herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: There is a little billet contain'd in this letter, where your ladyship promises a capital sum, when some certain services are fully perform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P:
By your leave, Sir James, let me look. Oh,
clear, clear, it is her hand, there is no denying of this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: I fancy Mrs. Kitty will own it. Otherwise my servant is below to confront her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Well, what reply do you make to all this?

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: I beg pardon, Sir, of my mistress, and you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: KITTY.
SP.P: I own the accusation is just, though I little thought Mr. Robin would betray me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Do you? and what an ungrateful wretch must you be? you have been but a poor instrument only. But is it possible you, Lady Riscounter, could so entirely forget what you owe to me, and your—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: I see, Sir Robert, you are so far prepossess'd, that all I can say—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Say, Madam, what can be said for such—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P:
Nay, Sir, I am not going to make a formal defence, it is not worth my while, nor would you have leisure to hear it: if you will walk
down, you will find another sort of business, that demands your attention.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: The house fill'd with a new kind of customers.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA, Sir ROBERT, Sir JAMES.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Only an extent, to seize on all his effects.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA, Sir ROBERT, Sir JAMES.
SP.P: Is it possible!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: The world will therefore see how ill I am treated—but don't imagine, Sir Robert, that the provision I derive from her father, shall be la∣vished to lessen your debts, or be employ'd in support of their author.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Your ladyship will have more prudence, no doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: No, child, we will quit this mansion directly, and leave him for consolation to the care of his daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P:
A more precious trust, I could never receive. Your treachery to me, Madam, I could both despise and forgive: but your insolent triumph, at the distress of an unfortunate husband, gives
you a pre-eminence above the worst of your sex. If, Sir, what you are pleased to call mine, can either reinstate, or assist you, I beg it may be all employ'd in the service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Nay, pr'ythee, Lydia—

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: You see, Sir James Biddulph, there are new obstables oppos'd to your purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: If you mean those her ladyship has been pleas∣ed to produce, they add only an additional strength to my wishes. The piety with which this great, this first duty is discharg'd, must ac∣company every other relation in life. I applaud, and shall be happy to join in your purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady RISCOUNTER.
SP.P: Come, Lucy, let us leave these romantick creatures together, they are only fit for each other; when your effects are convey'd to proper trustees, I shall take care to put in my claim.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Unfeeling, insolent woman; but thy good∣ness, Lydia, supplies every loss, nor will my cre∣ditors, when they find I never deceiv'd them, take advantage of thy filial affection.
What now?

SP.SPEAKER: CLERK.
SP.P: The Dutch mail is arrived.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Any private letters from Holland?

SP.SPEAKER: CLERK.
SP.P: Your correspondents, Sir, have honour'd your bills.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: And discharg'd them?

SP.SPEAKER: CLERK.
SP.P: Every one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: And the report of their failing—

SP.SPEAKER: CLERK.
SP.P: Was without the smallest foundation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: Heaven be prais'd; now, Lydya, thy fa∣ther can look again with confidence in the face of his friends.

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: A more real transport could never have reach'd me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: I know it, Lydia, I know it. This gentle∣man will both thank and reward you.

SP.SPEAKER: CLERK.
SP.P: Sir, I would beg just to—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: I guess what you mean; some inquisitive per∣sons below; they shall be satisfied soon. I will attend them directly.Exit Clerk.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: Give me leave to join in the general joy. But what, Sir Robert, shall we do with this paper? I fancy my man is in waiting; Robin.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBIN.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: You have been of singular service to-day, which I shall take good care to acknowledge. The worth of this note, as the conditions have fail'd—

SP.SPEAKER: ROBIN.
SP.P: Like many more of his kindred, is reduc'd to waste paper, your honour; but as this happy turn has been chiefly owing to Kitty, I hope she will be restor'd to favour again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES.
SP.P: But consider, Robin, that was not her inten∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBIN.
SP.P: But recollect, Sir, the temptation—five hun∣dred pounds—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P:
And then the treachery—But as many of her
superiors, tho' perhaps not her betters, are daily detected in doing things more criminal for less consideration, it is some excuse, I confess. But what says my Lydia?

SP.SPEAKER: LYDIA.
SP.P: I shall be directed by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: And now, my children, nothing remains but the last act, to establish your union, and if (as I am resolved to disengage myself from that bad woman, and the cares of this world) you will suffer me to be a partaker of this domestic feli∣city—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir JAMES, LYDIA.
SP.P: You cannot in any thing oblige us so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir ROBERT.
SP.P: That is all I have to ask of you, or the world.
